measured_by: Response Time in Puzzle Completion Task
justification: The study uses a pathfinding puzzle task where participant response time (fast vs. slow) in solving the puzzle is recorded to gauge children's ability to infer whether the agent was figuring out the answer or remembering it. This method measures children's intuitive understanding that thinking takes time.

measured_by: Judgment Accuracy of Agent's Answers Based on Speed
justification: Participants judged whether a faster or slower responding agent was more likely to have figured out the correct answer, integrating perceptions of speed with expected accuracy to assess the trade-offs between speed and accuracy in problem-solving.

measured_by: Participants' Ratings of Agent Competence Based on Response Time
justification: The experiment measures whether children can use an agent's response speed (fast or slow) to infer relative competence, as assessed by children’s judgments of which agent is better at solving the task after observing their response times.

measured_by: Inference Accuracy with Varying Map Difficulty
justification: Children's ability to integrate task difficulty into time-based inferences is measured by examining their judgments of the agent's response when presented with either easy or hard puzzles after observing their response time.
